instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BUTTON_DISABLE: What is BUTTON_DISABLE? BUTTON_DISABLE disables the trackpad when SMC_LID is below 0.5v and the system believes the lid is closed. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: I got in yesterday and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that I originally changed the backlight fuse and LCD cable on. I was unable to test the computers functionality before I returned it because I saw corrosion on the trackpad cable and the trackpad was not working. I told the customer to replace the cable and trackpad and they said they but the keyboard and track pad are not working. I looked at the cable and everything and it looks ok. Do I need to just do an SMC reset or something? or are there bigger issues?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message:
I recommend you to test known good working TP flex, becuase "new" chines flex always nightmare; maybe TP board too.
If still same, check basic voltages and signals to TP connector.

Next steps, check <RESISTOR>R5701</RESISTOR>-04 and change <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: So I checked the voltages to the TP connector and they appear to be in order. I get 3.3V on pins 17 and 19 and 5v on pin 18.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: would SMC Lid have anything to do with it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: I'm checking voltages on <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: So I checked pin 2 and pin 23 of the keyboard connector and i have both present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message:
J5700 power pins are 18 and 22.

"SMC Lid have anything to do with it?"
In fact you must check <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> signal.
High voltage will disable TP/KB.
And <TRANSISTOR>Q5701</TRANSISTOR> is driven by <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>...

Did you check all in <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> is at 0 volts. I am however showing a short to ground on the caps surrounding <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. Also, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_PSOC</SIGNAL> is 2.9v instead of 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: those caps are on the two VDD pins of <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. 13 ohms to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5704</RESISTOR> has correct value?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: yeah. pin 2 is 3.2v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: 2.9v on pin 1 side of <RESISTOR>R5704</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: I'm wondering if <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is dead. I did note allot of corrosion on the TPAD side of the connector and TPAD flex

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message:
Has <RESISTOR>R5704</RESISTOR> correct 1.5 ohm value???
Higher value points to bad <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: yes, it measured 1.6 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: can you tell me what the outputs of <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> are? I cannot tell but wanted to check.I measured <SIGNAL>TP_PSOC_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>TP_PSOC_SDA</SIGNAL> but do not have a frame of reference on if that is good or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message:
0.4V over 1.5 ohm is too much current consumption.
<CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is bad, or you have some corroded cap filters on its power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: Should I bother changing the Caps? or just replace <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: I should also note that Pin 51 which is <SIGNAL>PSOC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> is at 3.3V. does this mean <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is not AWAKE?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: Ok so I pulled off <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> to measure the caps around it and with the chip on they were all measuring 13 ohms to ground and now they are all measuring 14K ohms to ground. So is this definitive proof that <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: I don't know for sure if it is a bad idea or not but I quickly powered the board on to test the VDD in and it is now at 3.3v vs. the 2.9 that is was. I think this is a good sign, no?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: My theory is <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> was slightly damaged due to the corrosion on the TPAD and TPAD Flex. As a consequence the keyboard ceased to function as well. I believe this because other than that the computer works with USB mouse and I am not sure of the keyboard since I do not own an Apple keyboard. Please correct me if my thinking is wrong. I do not have a donor <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> at the moment I am sad to say. I assume since this is an MCU I will have to get it from a like model donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message:
Always good to get chips with firmware from donor board.
But you can compare different schematics and pull it off, if connector-chip traces have same configuration.
Give it a try, it may work...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Keyboard and track pad not working
threads.message: Good evening. So I was able to get a donor <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board to transplant <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. We now have a working keyboard and TPAD! So my theory was correct as well as your reccomendations :). The liquid damage that was on the TPAD and cable killed poor <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. The customer didn't know because they had no back light either. I replaced the BL fuse and restored BL but noted the keyboard and TPAD were not working possibly due to corrosion seen on the TPAD flex. On to the next one! Thanks 2informaticos!
